<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CreateSocketName:
```c
void OS_CreateSocketName(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *parent_name)
{
    size_t                       len;
    uint16                       port;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;

    sock = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    if (OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name), Addr) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock->stream_name[0] = 0;
    }
    if (OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(&port, Addr) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, ":%u", (unsigned int)port);
    }

    if (parent_name)
    {
        /* Append the name from the parent socket. */
        len = OS_strnlen(sock->stream_name, sizeof(sock->stream_name));
        snprintf(&sock->stream_name[len], sizeof(sock->stream_name) - len, "-%s", parent_name);
    }
}
```
</target_code>

int32 OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(char *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    const void *                  addrbuffer;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    if (inet_ntop(Accessor->sa.sa_family, addrbuffer, buffer, buflen) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}

int32 OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(uint16 *PortNum, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    in_port_t                     sa_port;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in.sin_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    *PortNum = ntohs(sa_port);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}

static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)

explanation: Only calls to functions from <string.h> (and their direct usages) are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The implementation of OS_strnlen calls memchr (a <string.h> function) and therefore must be investigated to ensure memchr does not access beyond the bounds of the object referenced by s. Also the two places in OS_CreateSocketName that call OS_strnlen should be inspected to confirm that the buffer and length arguments supplied satisfy the precondition that the pointer references at least maxlen bytes (i.e. that sizeof(sock->stream_name) is the actual object size passed and that the buffer is initialized/valid at the time of the call). Other fragments (the snprintf calls, the calls to inet_ntop/OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl, OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl, and the use of snprintf with parent_name) are not direct uses of the <string.h> functions covered by Rule 21.17: snprintf is from <stdio.h>, inet_ntop is from <arpa/inet.h>/network libraries, and OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl does not call any <string.h> functions. Therefore those are outside the strict scope of Rule 21.17 and are not reported here.
